Is Re:Zero worth watching? I've seen it around a lot recently.

Don't accept instant yes/no answers on this, because it depends entirely on the kind of anime fan you are.

If it's easy for you to get really invested in something and turn off your brain, then yes watch it b/c you'll probably have fun with it no matter what critics say.

* Alternatively: Do you think SAO's first season wasn't that bad? 

* If yes, watch RE: Zero.

If you're the type of person who analyzes a show as you watch it, has reasonably high standards, or does not easily get invested in a show, then you should probably skip Re:Zero b/c you'll probably find it to be below average and wonder how it got so much attention.

* Alternatively: Do you think SAO's first season still made mistakes that you couldn't overlook/forgive? 

* If yes, skip RE: Zero.

Definitely agree with this.  Don't look for the meaning of life in Re:Zero, but if you can laze through lower quality anime or can forgive them enough to watch them then it is at least trying.  Got about half way to three quarters of the way myself before I just kinda lost interest.  

I am pretty forgiving of anime so long as they don't keep making the same mistakes, I just found that Re:Zero didn't really evolve throughout it.  Some interesting parts, not many _bad_ parts, but a fair bit of blandness for those who like to dig deep into an anime.

SAO comparison was a very good one though.
It's a must watch.  Very good.
I wouldn't say a must watch. But if you want a ~~depressing~~ fresh,~~torturous~~ entertaining anime to watch, then it's highly recommendable.

Felix the Trap is obviously best girl.
What really got me laughing was the best girl poll at the end. Like that came out of nowhere. Though the answer is obvious: Fel-I mean Rem....yeah, Rem.

Straight guys kind of have to blot out the whole "Felix is actually a dude" thing. If it weren't for that, it'd be a tough decision.

Went through the whole series telling myself "Nope, that was a mistranslation. I don't care what it says, that's a chick."

Heh, luckily I am bisexual, so everything is open.  That being said Rem is still best waifu, not that Felix is bad.  Solid number 2.

(Bisexuality also makes watching boxbox's cosplay of Riven/Rem much better for those interested.)

The hell breaks loose for me when trying to discuss the characters.  

Me: "Oh yeah I love the part where..... The... guy with brown hair?  Y'know, the one who messes with the protagonist like halfway through..."

Friend: "Oh yeah you mean <insert generic anime name here>!"

Me: "Yeah that one!  I love the part where <generic anime name> does <generic anime thing>!"

K, so it's not only me, but can you tell me, does every anime have a beach or overall bikini-related special? When I saw it in first 3 anime I watched i was like srsly? But when I heard from friend that Bleach also has one, jeez, it's about slayi... saving souls with a big sword and ginger hair, also about Aizen betraying everyone (btw the same friend, when asked her after Aizen's "death" if he faked it and will be the bad guy, and she said to not tell the future, so I kinda got spoilers for next 10 episodes), but k, why not, special is special. BUT THEN IN FREAKIN ZERO NO TSUKAIMA, ANIME IN OTHER FREAKIN WORLD, IN THE (CHECKS THE WORD CUZ BAD ENGLISH) FREAKIN MEDIEVAL, BEACH AND BIKINI, SRSLY? FREAKIN SRSLY? Also, when i saw how much episodes Naruto and Shippuden have, did ANYONE watch it whole?

It is for one of two reasons that anime have episodes like that.  Reason 1)  That is just the type of anime they are because it sells well.  Reason 2)  Filler episodes while waiting for the manga to catch up and they sell well.

Most Naruto fans were watching when there were 100 or less episodes, so they watched them as they came out, not all at once.

If you want to avoid bikini/beach episode anime you have to look in the less popular side of anime.  Generally things on the more psychological end of the spectrum.  Horror anime have a tendency to avoid it as well as some of the smaller more tasteful anime.

Off the top of my head relating to each of those categories that don't have bikini style episodes there is Serial Experiments Lain (Anime from back in 1998 about how technology was going to influence the world and the merging of internet and real life.  Surprising prophetic although not an easy show to relax to.  Requires a lot of deep thinking.) Another (Book/Manga/Anime ghost story horror thing.  Haven't actually seen the whole anime yet but I know it is very true to the book which I love.)  Tasteful anime that fall closer to the normal end of the spectrum but avoid that stuff include things like Silver Spoon (Romantic Comedy in a quite realistic way.  Really good watch actually because the romance in it is very realistic even if it goes over the top in other areas.)

There are also anime that just make a joke of it or include it because believe it or not people go to the beach.  Log Horizon is a personal favourite example of this (And just a personal favourite).  Sure there is a beach episode but it directly relates to the story and it takes place at the beach because another location was required to make it work.  The reason it was at a beach was due to there being a training camp near the ocean and one of the side characters who had a role in organizing it very much being the type of person who would detour for that.  Log Horizon also isn't afraid to use sexual themes in a fairly realistic way because people are attractive, and there are people who use that attractiveness.

I thought that Ao No Exorcist has no beach episodes... WRONG! Forgot about the one with kraken. I don't like anime horrors too much, because they are just bloody as hell, and I think that horrors should make you shit your pants just by ambient sounds and creepy place ot action, story, sometimes the jumpscare, maybe the creature trying to kill you or anime characters too, but not just blood, violence or corpses. Good example would be FNAF, Slender, or Death By Daylight.

Another isn't actually that bloody from what I remember.  It is halfway between a murder mystery and horror anime.  The deaths themselves are bloody, but not.... gory?  Almost every death in it is due to an "accident" and while there may be blood involved there isn't like hallways of blood.  They use blood as a tool to show the horror but the horror is from the story.

I'll check, I remember I watched one horror anime, and well, I think it was gore, Corpse Party if i remember correctly, so I judged too early, I'll see that for sure, but atm I'm watching 7 anime at the same time, so kinda 8th will be too much.

Oooh yeah corpse party is definitely on the bloody end of the spectrum.  Would not use that as a basis to judge them all although I wouldn't go in expecting any kind of horror anime not to have blood.
Well, I don't say blood is someting bad in horror, but using more of bloody stuff and less of this spooky atmosphere, makes it a lot less scary for me.

Yeah as I said I only saw a bit of the Anime (got sidetracked) but I have heard a lot about how it is very true to the book and in the book it was all about the atmosphere and mystery/confusion going on which is fueled by the death but the death isn't the focus in and of itself.

Hmmm I really want to reread Another right now haha.  Maybe after that I will finally get around to watching the anime and not getting sidetracked this time.
